body: LGTM

So for current `ContainerPoolBalancer`, has need to do like this?

The tests rely on those images so the tests should have a dependency on them, no?

You can always create a specific test-target which excludes those dependencies, which I'd prefer here.
@csantanapr PG4 1344 🔵

That’s also good to create a new target for environments were a specific image tag want to be use and avoid the rebuild and trashed on what’s already prepared. Like a lean target that skips this dependencies assuming that those are already taken care. 

The use case is for the CI/CD of Apache release automation where a specific tag of the runtimes would be use and build before running the tests.

rebased to latest master; PG1/2612 🏃
@markusthoemmes ,can you loot at this again?

@ningyougang would you mind adding a test? You can have a look at the PR @rabbah mentioned. I tested the randomness by checking that every invoker is scheduled to in 100 schedules and by asserting that the unhealthys are not in that sequence even once.

@markusthoemmes , it seems `random` although good, it is still not perfect, in long time, it is `fairly`, but in a short time, `random` may not `failly`, may lead to some invoker nodes's action is more, but some others is `less`.

How do i found  the problem?
Becuase i am testing the `zerodowntime deployment`, during `disable one invoker` short time, above  problem exist.

So i suggest to improve like below
```
      invokerProgression
        .find(_._3 < invokerBusyThreshold)
        .orElse(invokerProgression.find(_._3 < invokerBusyThreshold * 2))
        .orElse(invokerProgression.find(_._3 < invokerBusyThreshold * 3))
        .orElse(
          if (invokerProgression.isEmpty)
            None
          else
            Some(invokerProgression.minBy(_._3)))
        .map(_._1)
```

through ` Some(invokerProgression.minBy(_._3)))`, when all invokers are overloaded, the lb will chose the least number of invoker node to execute.

How do you think?

As @rabbah would put it: Randomness generally helps against pathologies. Your `minBy` makes sense in homogenous load but once you start getting activations with different lengths, runtimes etc. using `minBy` might create a pathology.

That said, it's the overflow case anyway so we cannot optimize that much. The overflow case will never be "perfect".
ok, i think so, i will add the test case
Great PR!
@markusthoemmes ,i have added the test case, please review again.
I have rebased the PR to current master. Its ready to be merged from my side. Let me know if anything else needs to be addressed as part of this PR (coverage in docker runs would be dealt later)

Understand the problem now. As discussed on Slack the plan of action is to  find out all other projects which rely on openwhisk core project via project dependency and then modify them in following way

Switch to Maven based dependency

	repositories {
	    mavenCentral()
	    mavenLocal()
	}
    dependencies {
        compile "org.apache.openwhisk:openwhisk-common:${gradle.openwhisk.version}"    
    }

Modify travis build to perform Maven install

    ./gradlew install distDocker

Based on [this search][1] there are 7 such modules which need to be modified. This change also aligns well with the release work where eventually we would be moving to proper dependency

Would work on creating PR for each of them

Update - Opened #3277 to track this change

[1]: https://sourcegraph.com/search?q=%22project%28%27:common:scala%27%29%22+repo:%5Egithub%5C.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk*
Excellent update. Thank you!
rebased on top of #3256

Updated `logs` field in the trigger activation record will look like the following for a trigger with one active and one inactive rule:
```
    "logs": [
        "{\"statusCode\":0,\"success\":true,\"activationId\":\"a0e1a50ba6074eeca1a50ba6072eecdc\",\"rule\":\"guest/activerule1\",\"action\":\"guest/web-echo-env\"}",
        "{\"statusCode\":1,\"success\":false,\"rule\":\"guest/inactiverule1\",\"error\":\"Rule guest/inactiverule1 is inactive; action guest/web-echo-env was not activated\",\"action\":\"guest/web-echo-env\"}"
    ],
```

Am I blocking this?  I _think_ I've answered all the comments and this PR is ripe for another review, but please let me know if there's anything I should be doing at this end

Turned out to be two different bugs.
1. Updating a rule with `wsk rule update` always returned a status of active. 
2. After updating a rule with `wsk rule update` the status would be inactive when the rule is fetched with `wsk rule get`.

> In Scala 2.10, scala.reflect.ClassManifest are deprecated, and it is planned to deprecate scala.reflect.Manifest in favor of TypeTags and ClassTags in an upcoming point release. Thus, it is advisable to migrate any Manifest-based APIs to use Tags.

Manifest is not deprecated but planned to be deprecated at some point. Can you provide an implementation example of where a `ClassTag` would be needed?

Good thought! Is there a possibility to hook stuff up differently? I think the issue here is that `createKeystore` is run after compiling. Is it maybe possible to hook it up to "preRun" or something? That'd make this more clear.

> Can you provide an implementation example of where a ClassTag would be needed?

Have a look at [MongoDbStoreProvider][1] (currently work in progress) which needs this info to [compute fields](chetanmeh/openwhisk-mongo#8)

[1]: https://github.com/chetanmeh/openwhisk-mongo/blob/master/common/mongo/src/main/scala/whisk/core/database/mongo/MongoDbStoreProvider.scala#L55

Okay makes sense.

This is a bit smelly though. It suggests we have a generalized API for something which shouldn't be generalized? Since we already have the `WhiskAuthStore`, `WhiskEntityStore`, `WhiskActivationStore` objects to construct entity stores, would it make sense to rather widen the constructor of `ArtifactStore`? What is the type of `WhiskHandler` for instance?

> It suggests we have a generalized API for something which shouldn't be generalized?

Its kind of true as with CouchDB most of query logic is implemented as code in CouchDB side which can be treated as implementation detail for CouchDbRestStore where the (designDoc, viewName) parameter maps to the server side logic.

For non CouchDB stores this would need to be implemented as part of store implementation. 

Another usecase is type of index being created which would differ for various stores and would differ based on persistent store.

Hence using entity/document type as selector for such logic

> Is it maybe possible to hook it up to "preRun" or something? 

Good point. Updated the PR to use a different approach which binds the createKeystore with all test tasks. So now it would only be triggered if any test task is invoked

@rabbah Yes, we will loose the ability to count activations per namespace with Kamon.
I can't recall -- is there a good reason we can't support bound actions as web actions?

@sjfink 
>I can't recall -- is there a good reason we can't support bound actions as web actions?

I can't recall, I vaguely remember something that user can't write the annotation `web-export` to the action, since it doesn't own the action to attached the annotation.
Also something about the annotation needs to be on the action not on a package as it would make all the actions  in the package a web action.

I bet @rabbah and @dubeejw can clarify since they worked on that code.

The restriction follows from design choices that I made:

- web annotation is attached to an action
- an action in a public package cannot be amended by a subject unless they own it

So if a packaged action is made into a web action, we’d force all bindings to inherit the annotation for the action. And we don’t have a mechanism that allows a binding to override and modify an action from the base package.
FWIW: I'm assembling a PR which will catch this in the future and fail the travis build if a test is missing the annotation. A bit embarrassing. Thanks for catching! 🎉

LGTM. I think we’ll need to rethink the artifact store as we’ve made several singnifcant changes since initial conception and can simplify some of the generic typing which gets in the way; this led to a whole of code duplication in WhiskActionMetadata for example.
We definitly should, yes. @rabbah

+1 allowing an update of a trigger with a feed if one is not attached makes sense. The current restriction was intended to prevent a trigger that is already attached to a feed to participate in another feed which replaces the first - and neglecting to disable the first feed. With a trigger that does not have an attached feed, there is no such concern.

The `wsk` CLI does not offer `--feed` on `wsk trigger update` and will need to also be updated.
